{{Infobox person | name = Salvador Minguijón Adrián | image = Salvador Minguijon.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Juan Salvador Minguijón Adrián | birth_date = 1874 | birth_place = [[Calatayud]] | death_date = 1959 | death_place = [[Zaragoza]] | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = academic, theorist | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = academic | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]], [[:es:Partido Social Popular|Partido Social Popular]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = Firma de Salvador Minguijon.png | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }} '''Salvador Minguijón Adrián''' (1874-1959) was a Spanish law scholar, political theorist and politician. As a lawyer he is known mostly as a longtime academic in the [[University of Zaragoza]] and briefly member of the [[Supreme Court of Spain|Spanish constitutional court]]. As a theorist he is considered one of key representatives of [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalism]]. As a politician he is recognized as associated with [[Carlism]], [[Christian Democracy]], [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primoderiverismo]], [[Social Catholicism]] and early [[Francoism]].
==Family and youth== [[File:Vista de Calatayud desde la iglesia de La Peña, España, 2012-08-24, DD 02.JPG|thumb|left|[[Calatayud]]]] Juan Salvador Minguijón Adrián was descendant to an [[Aragon]]ese family of petty officials and artisans. His paternal ancestors originated from the village of [[Terrer]] in South-Western Aragon, where Salvador's grandfather worked as a primary school teacher;<ref>Juan Francisco Baltar Rodriguez, ''Minguijón y Adrián, Juan Salvador (1874-1959)'', [in:] ''Diccionario de catedráticos españoles de derecho'' online, 2014, available [http://portal.uc3m.es/portal/page/portal/instituto_figuerola/programas/phu/diccionariodecatedraticos/lcatedraticos/jsminguijon here]</ref> his son and Salvador's father, [[Jorge Minguijón Cacho]]<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 21.05.90, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0004878726&page=3 here]</ref> (died 1895),<ref>''El Movimiento Católico'' 31.12.95, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0025558333&page=7 here]</ref> was a local administrative clerk.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> At unspecified date he married María Antonia Adrián Martínez, herself from the nearby [[Calatayud]]. Her family originated from [[Visiedo]] in another Aragonese [[province of Teruel]];<ref>though they lived in Calatayud, Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> Salvador's maternal grandfather worked as a carpenter.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> The couple had at least two sons, though exact number of their children is not clear.
Salvador and his brother were raised in a profoundly religious ambience; his father was a local Catholic activist<ref>''La Unión Católica'' 21.05.90</ref> and his brother was to become a friar.<ref>''El Salmantino'' 05.09.17, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=5041979&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Following childhood spent in Calatayud the young Salvador entered a diocesan seminary in [[Zaragoza]], a path typically leading to a career of a priest or a school teacher.<ref>Gonzalo Díaz Díaz, ''Minguijón Adrián, Salvador'', [in:] ''Hombres y documentos de la filosofía española'', vol 5, Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|9788400075040}}, p. 529</ref> Having completed the schooling at unspecified time he enrolled at [[Universidad de Zaragoza]], commencing learning at the faculty of Filosofía y Letras, where he completed the curriculum and graduated in 1896.<ref>Juan Francisco Baltar Rodriguez, ''Los ejercisios de oposiciones a profesor auxiliar de Salvador Minguijón'', [in:] ''European Journal of Legal History'' 10 (2013), p. 72</ref> He then moved to Madrid to pursue studies in law at [[:es:Universidad de Madrid|Universidad Central]]; having been awarded a [[Cum laude|Cum Laude diploma]] in 1900, Minguijón continued with doctoral research.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72</ref>
In 1903 Minguijón commenced the career of a lawyer becoming a notary in [[Sabiñán]], a municipio in the comarca of Calatayud. In 1905 he switched to the same role in [[Brea de Aragón|Brea]], a slightly larger location in the [[Aranda (comarca)|comarca of Aranda]],<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 529</ref> where he probably practiced very shortly as he soon commenced academic duties in Zaragoza. In 1906 Minguijón obtained [[PhDs|PhD laurels]] in Madrid; his thesis, titled ''La responsabilidad civil extracontractual'', was considered excellent by the jury.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72</ref> [[File:Paracuellos Fosa III.JPG|thumb|[[Paracuellos de Jarama]] cemetery]] At unspecified time Salvador Minguijón married Ana-María Paraíso Ferruz;<ref>''ABC'' 12.07.35, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1935/07/12/055.html here]</ref> none of the sources consulted provides any information on his wife. The couple had 4 children: Carmen, Agustín, María Luisa and María Antonia.<ref>''ABC'' 12.05.35</ref> The family lived in Zaragoza, though in the mid-1930s they moved to [[Madrid]].<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 530</ref> Minguijón spent his declining years alone: his brother died in 1917,<ref>''El Salmantino'' 05.09.17</ref> his wife widowed him middle-aged in 1935,<ref>''ABC'' 12.07.35</ref> one daughter became a [[Discalced Carmelites|Discalced Carmelitan]] [[nun]] and has never left the monastery, the only son, a leading activist of [[:es:Asociación Católica de Propagandistas|Asociación Católica Nacional de Propagandistas]],<ref>José Luis Orella Martínez, ''El origen del primer Catolicismo social Español'' [PhD thesis, Universidad de Educación a Distancia], Madrid 2012, p. 429</ref> was executed by the [[Republican faction (Spanish Civil War)|Republicans]] in [[Paracuellos massacres|Paracuellos de Jarama]] in 1936,<ref>''Agustín Minguijón Paraíso (1907-1936)'' [in:] ''Asociacion Catolica de Progapandistas'' service, available [http://www.acdp.es/agustin-minguijon-paraiso-1907-1936/ here]; there is a monograph dedicated to Minguijón Paraíso, see José Vicente Rodríguez, ''Le troncharon en la flor de la vida. Agustín Minguijón Paraíso. Datos biográficos y martirios (1907-1936)'', Zaragoza 2009, {{ISBN|9788483532454}}</ref> while another daughter died in the mid-1940s.<ref>referred after Rafael Gambra, ''Aspectos del pensamiento de Salvador Minguijón'', [in:] ''Revista international de sociologia'' 67 (1959), p. 85; it is not clear what happened to his third daughter</ref> Minguijón passed away in Zaragoza,<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72</ref> en route to his usual summer holiday location in [[Irún]].<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref>
==Jurist: academic and official== [[File:Paraninfo Zaragoza 1.JPG|thumbnail|left|[[Zaragoza University]]]] In 1904-1905 Minguijón applied to a number of secondary education institutions in Zaragoza, but his bids for chairs of geography,<ref>chairs of geografía descriptiva general de Europa y de España in Instituto de Mahón (Zaragoza) and Instituto de Baeza (Zaragoza)</ref> history,<ref>chairs of historia de España e historia universal in Instituto de Mahón and Instituto de Baeza</ref> letters,<ref>lengua y literatura castellana in Instituto de Baeza</ref> Latin<ref>chairs of Latin language in Instituto de Canarias (Zaragoza) and in Instituto de Figueras (Zaragoza)</ref> and law<ref>chair of psicología, lógica, ética y rudimentos de Derecho in Instituto de Teruel (Zaragoza)</ref> proved unsuccessful.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> In 1905 he was accepted at temporary unpaid job of professor auxiliar at Facultad de Derecho of the Zaragoza University;<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, pp. 72-73</ref> the same year he defeated 5 counter-candidates and won the contest for professor auxiliar interino retribuido del segundo grupo,<ref>detailed discussion of academic contest in Baltar Rodriguez 2013, pp. 71-87</ref> assuming regular teaching duties in 1906. In 1907 he was promoted to professor auxiliar numerario de segundo grupo.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> The same year he filled the vacancy in Historia General del Derecho Español as assistant professor.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 73</ref> In 1910 he applied for Historia General del Derecho in [[Universidad de Valladolid]], but it is not clear whether he took part in usual contest for the job.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> In 1911 he emerged victorious from the contest for chair of Historia General del Derecho in Zaragoza, thus terminating the period of junior assignments and assuming a major academic position.<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 529, Baltar Rodriguez 2014, p. 72</ref>
Minguijón served as head of history of law in Zaragoza almost for the following quarter of the century, his position in national realm of jurisprudence scholars enhanced following publication of a series of textbooks in the 1910s and especially his major work, ''Historia del Derecho Español'', issued in 1927. Since the mid-1910s he was being invited as jury member in contests for academic chairs, held across Spain.<ref>Facultad de Derecho de Santiago de Compostela (1915) and cátedra de Historia del Derecho de la Universidad de Murcia (1919), Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 73</ref> In the early 1930s he was already a distinguished law academic, known beyond the scientific milieu thanks to his numerous press contributions. Minguijón's juridical career was crowned in 1933, when he was elected as an academic nominee to [[:es:Tribunal de Garantías Constitucionales (España)|Tribunal de Garantías Constitucionales]], the Spanish constitutional court.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72</ref> The year marked also his departure from Zaragoza; he had to abandon the university chair as the new job required his presence in Madrid. [[File:Tribunal Supremo de España (Madrid) 01.jpg|thumbnail|site of [[Supreme Court of Spain|Tribunal Supremo]]]] Minguijón formally resigned from the anyway defunct Tribunal in September 1936; he returned to Zaragoza and resumed his university duties<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, pp. 72-73</ref> until in 1938<ref>''Minguijón y Adrián, Juan Salvador'' [in:] ''Gran Enciclopedia Aragonesa'' online, available [http://www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com/voz.asp?voz_id=8834 here]</ref> he was appointed to the new Francoist high court, [[Supreme Court of Spain|Tribunal Supremo]].<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72</ref> Back in Madrid, in the early 1940s he chaired historia del derecho and sociología at Universidad Central.<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 530</ref> In 1940 he entered the very elite of Spanish academics, becoming a member of the [[Real Academia de Ciencias Morales y Políticas]].<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, pp. 73</ref> Minguijón resigned from all academic and official duties upon reaching the regular retirement age in 1944.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> Already in the 1930s he used to collaborate with semi-scholarly institutions, notably giving lectures at [[Ateneo de Madrid]].<ref>Gambra 1959, pp. 82-85</ref> This activity gained momentum following his retirement, especially as he became vice-president of the 1943-established [[Instituto Balmes de Sociología]].<ref>Jesús Tobío Fernández, ''Salvador Minguijón Adrián'', [in:] ''Arbor'' 44 (1959), p. 217</ref> Already in the early 1940s he engaged in works of [[:es:Institución Fernando el Católico|Institución Fernando el Católico]] of Zaragoza.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> In 1944 he became one of the moving spirits behind the Madrid [[Colegio de Aragón]], set up by IFC as means of sustaining an Aragon identity,<ref>Gustavo Alares López, Severino Aznar y el Colegio de Aragón (1945-1959), Zaragoza 2013, {{ISBN|9788499112657}}, p. 39</ref> scaling down his engagement after 1953.<ref>he was last noted as taking part in regular meeting in 1953, Alares López 2013, p. 267, for later years see Alares López 2013, p. 268 and onwards</ref>
==Writings== [[File:Alfonso X de Castilla (1255, edición 1543) Fuero Real de España.png| thumb|160px| left| ''Fuero Real'', 1543 (1255)]] Minguijón's written heritage is one major work, around 20 booklets, tens of scientific articles and hundreds of press items. In terms of topics, his opus is described by a present-day-scholar as multi-faceted.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72</ref> It may be roughly divided into 4 groups: [[jurisprudence]], [[political thought]], [[social sciences]] and ongoing public issues.
His most recognized works are those dealing with [[history of law]]. From 1911 to the early 1920s Minguijón published booklets formatted as textbooks for students, completed as a 12-volume series titled ''Elementos de historia del derecho español'';<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> apart from synthesis and update of earlier works they were heavily based on own research, related in particular to medieval and foral Spanish legislation.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 74</ref> The series was a basis for a massive monograph, ''Historia del derecho español'' (1927), the 500-page work which gained Minguijón his name and scientific posture. Re-issued in few editions, until the mid-1950s it served as academic manual for generations of Spanish students.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref>
Minguijón's works on political thought were formatted mostly as pamphlets and booklets hardly exceeding 100 pages. The best known one, having been also chronologically the first, was ''La crisis del tradicionalismo en España'' (1914), a lecture of author's understanding of Traditionalism and its role in Spain of the era; it elevated the author to a prominent though controversial position within Carlism. It was followed by ''Humanismo y nacionalidad'' (1929), ''Al servicio de la Tradición'' (1930), ''La crisis de la libertad'' (1934), ''La Democracia'' (1934) and ''Los apologistas del siglo II'' (1936), all of them marking an attempt to transform Traditionalist outlook into a modern Christian doctrine.<ref>he also father minor works, often focusing on specific individuals like Baltasar Gracián, Antonio Maura, Juan Moneva, see e.g. ''El sentido de la vida en la obras de Gracián'' [in:] ''Baltasar Gracián escritor aragonés del s. XVII'', Zaragoza 1926</ref> [[File:ULL.98.45.71.33.jpg|thumb|160px|''[[El Debate]]'', 1918]] Minguijón's interest in social issues gradually developed into a hybrid in-between the science of [[sociology]] and theories of addressing social problems. It was first demonstrated in ''Las luchas del periodismo'' (1908), a discussion of social obligations of the press,<ref>the work despised subordination of intellectuals to the rule of capital, José Manuel Gonzalez Torga, ''Fenomenologia de los confidenciales como modalidad del periodismo'' [PhD thesis Complutense], Madrid 1994, p. 452</ref> followed by ''Hombres e ideas. Estudios sociales'' (1910), ''Propiedad y trabajo'' (1920), ''La función social de la propiedad'' (1930) and ''La Propiedad'' (1935) and combined with numerous articles in specialized reviews.<ref>especially ''Revista Católica de las cuestiones sociales''; the periodical he contributed to from 1911 to 1930. Compare also ''Sobre el objeto de la sociología'', [in:] ''Revista Internacional de Sociología'' 4/6 (1943-1944), ''La Cuestión de Progreso'' [in:] ''Revista Internacional de Sociología'', 8-9 (1944-1945), ''Vulgarización Sociológica, Opinión y Masa'' [in:] ''Revista Internacional de Sociología'' 19 (1947)</ref> Some works fall rather into philosophy, as Minguijón strove to present a general background of Christian thought; they are either a handful of minor works published for limited audience<ref>see e.g. ''Lo racional y lo irracional en el mundo físico'' [in:] ''Arbor'' 9 (1945), ''En torno al Espacio'' [in:] ''Segunda Reunión de Aproximación Filosófico-Científica'', Zaragoza 1959, ''En torno a la Materia'' [in:] ''La Materia: III Reunión de Aproximación Filosófico-Científica',' Zaragoza 1961, ''La obra social de Costa'', Zaragoza 1926</ref> or translations from German.<ref>Minguijón translated two works of Martin Grabmann: ''Filosofía medieval'' (1928) and ''Santo Tomás de Aquino'' (1930), and one of Robert F. Arnold, ''Cultura del Renacimiento'' (1928)</ref>
A numerically dominating group of Minguijón's writings are his press contributions, usually some 800-word commentaries dealing with ongoing public affairs. Far from partisan zeal and styled as impartial essays, within a wide public discourse they gained Minguijón recognition of a pundit. Starting the early 1910s he began to contribute to Catholic dailies across the country.<ref>like ''Heraldo Alaves'', ''El Salmantino'', ''Diario de Valencia'', ''La Gaceta de Tenerife'', ''Diario de Alicante'' or ''Diario de Reus''</ref> However, he was particularly active writing to ''[[El Debate]]'' and emerged as key commentator of the Madrid daily. As during the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] years ''El Debate'' became a semi-official [[CEDA]] mouthpiece, Minguijón, at that time member of the supreme national court, preferred to publish rather in various regional Catholic periodicals.<ref>''Region'', ''El bien publico'', ''Heraldo de Almeria'', ''El dia de Palencia'', ''Labor'', ''La Gaceta de Tenerife'' and others</ref> During the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] and afterwards he did not resume his career of a press pundit.
==Carlist: ''minimismo''== [[File:Salvador Minguijón.png|thumbnail|170px|left|Salvador Minguijón (1911)]] Political preferences of Minguijón's father are not entirely clear, though he is known to have at least sympathized with Carlism.<ref>''La Regeneración'' 09.12.69, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026688647&page=1 here]</ref> A "Salvador Minguijón" from Calatayud was noted as signing a loyalist Carlist address in 1886,<ref>''El Cabecilla'' 04.12.89, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003848511&page=3 here]</ref> but for the first time he can be surely identified assuming public activity in 1897, taking part in local ecclesiastical educational initiatives.<ref>''La Voz de la Provincia'' 03.04.97, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=2295057&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> He followed an apparent periodista zeal: in 1908 he took part in a Catholic Asamblea Nacional de Buena Prensa,<ref>''El Día de Palencia'' 30.09.08, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2191179&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> while in the 1910s co-founded and periodically managed socially minded Catholic periodicals, ''La paz social'',<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 530, Sergio Fernández Riquelme, ''Sociología, corporativismo y política social en España'' [PhD thesis Universidad de Murcia], Murcia 2008, p. 214. In 1913 he travelled across Europe to see the nascent Christian-Democratic initiatives first-hand, Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 73</ref> ''El Noticiero''<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 530</ref> and ''El Pilar''.<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 14.01.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000610641&page=4 here]</ref> His Carlist leaning was reinforced at the University; in the early 20th century the Zaragoza Law Faculty was dominated by [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Jaimistas]] from the [[Jesus Comin Sagues|Comín]] dynasty.<ref>Bienvenido Comín Sarté and Pascual Comín Moya</ref> However, he was not noted as active within the Carlist realm until publication of ''La crisis del tradicionalismo en España'' in 1914.<ref>he is not a single time mentioned in a lengthy study on marques de Cerralbo, the most complete recent scholarly history of Carlism between the 1880s and 1910s, see Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012</ref>
''La crisis'' claimed that Traditionalist dogma was perfectly valid, though it had to be renewed and its application re-defined; Minguijón viewed it not as a fixed set of principles, but as an adaptive approach to problems of human civilization.<ref>Gambra 1959, p. 86</ref> The practical conclusion was that the Carlists should seek alliance with all political forces sharing the same lowest common denominator. He advocated rapprochement with the [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrists]], with [[Lliga Regionalista]] and with the [[Antonio Maura|Mauristas]]. Indeed, some claim that he subscribed to a "modelo maurrasiano", a new counter-revolutionary movement<ref>Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 204</ref> exploring parliamentary opportunities to build a confessional, corporative and regional state;<ref>Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 197</ref> others underline inspiration by the concept of Catholic unity, launched by ACNDP and pursued by its freshly set up daily, ''El Debate''.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 106, 115</ref> The alliance implied that the Carlists should soften their approach to [[Catalanism]], up to recognition of separate Catalan legislation and administration,<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, ''Umierać ale powoli'', Kraków 2002, {{ISBN|8386225742}}, p. 288, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 123</ref> and park their dynastical claims.<ref>Bartyzel 2002, p. 288</ref> Some scholars consider Minguijón's strategy a reference to [[Sexenio Democrático]], when Carlism served as agglutinatory factor for conservative forces;<ref>Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, p. 267</ref> it was supposed to lay path for peaceful transformation of liberal monarchy into a traditionalist one.<ref>Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}, p. 83</ref> The strategy presented was dubbed "minimismo"<ref>Canal 2000, p. 267, Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 83, 247, 248</ref> or "minimismo tradicionalista".<ref>José Andrés Gallego, Antón M. Pazos (eds.), ''Archivo Gomá: Febrero de 1937'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|9788400080570}}, p. 353</ref> [[File:Jaime de Borbón y Borbón-Parma.png|thumb|[[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]], 1910s]] Within Carlism Minguijón's proposal was appreciated as an elaborated and genuine attempt to revitalize the movement, though the critics pointed out that it would be another version of [[:es:Alejandro Pidal y Mon|Pidalismo]],<ref>Bartyzel 2002, p. 288</ref> an opportunist amalgamation of Traditionalism within a broad conservative spectrum. They lambasted it as "reducción grave y transcendental de las bases más esenciales de nuestra Comunión"<ref>opinion of Mariano Fortuny, quoted after Canal 2000, p. 268, see also Andrés Martín 2000, p. 83</ref> and amputation of Carlism.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 83</ref> Skeptics offered a competitive diagnosis, namely that the crisis of Carlism was caused by the deadly virus of parliamentarism.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 84</ref> Following a period of hesitation, in 1915 Minimismo was eventually disavowed by the claimant [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]], who confirmed intransigence on dynastical issues and permitted at best neutral approach towards moderate Catalanism of La Lliga.<ref>Bartyzel 2002, p. 288; opposite view in Andrés Martín 2000, p. 84, namely that Don Jaime himself reduced dynastic thread to secondary position</ref>
==''Mellismo'' and Partido Social Popular== [[File:Juan Vazquez de Mella 1906.JPG|thumb|160px|left|[[Juan Vázquez de Mella]]]] In the 1910s Carlism was dominated by a conflict between the claimant and the key party theorist, [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]]. At a first glance Minimismo and [[Mellismo]] seemed alike: both favored parking dynastical issues and forging a grand, Traditionalism-centred Right-wing alliance. However, scholars differ when discussing mutual position of the two concepts. Some name Minguijón a key protagonist of "sector promellista", highlighting their shared penchant for a conservative bloc;<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 83</ref> others note rather that Minguijón followed de Mella by firmly incorporating the social dimension into the doctrine.<ref>Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 197</ref> Some students, however, suggest that Minguijón opposed "catastrofismo mellista" by working towards a constructive solution.<ref>Canal 2000, p. 267</ref> They highlight that Minguijón seemed inclined towards politics within the [[Alfonsism|Alfonsist]] framework,<ref>e.g. when courted by [[Angel Ossorio y Gallardo]] in 1914</ref> while de Mella adopted a decisively anti-system stance with no dynastical commitments.<ref>Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 337</ref> One more difference was that unlike a fiercely Germanophile de Mella, during the [[First World War|Great War]] Minguijón adopted a pro-[[Entente Cordiale|Entente]] stand and even considered setting up a pro-French daily.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 127-8</ref>
When the crisis climaxed in 1919 and the Mellistas broke away to build their own grouping, Minguijón maintained loyalty to Don Jaime. According to some sources he remained influential enough to enforce – together with [[Francisco Martín Melgar y Rodríguez|Francisco Melgar]] - resignation of [[Pascual Comín y Moya]] from the temporary Carlist leadership. However, his days in the movement were already numbered. Together with a group of socially-minded Zaragoza scholars he had been co-operating with for more than a decade, especially Severino Aznar and [[Inocencio Jiménez]],<ref>though periodically also with Maximiliano Arboleya, José Calvo Sotelo or Reig Genovés</ref> in 1919 he co-founded Grupo de Democracía Cristiana, an organization under the auspices of [[Victoriano Guisasola y Menéndez|cardinal Guiasola]].<ref>Fernández Riquelme 2008, pp. 218-9, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 190</ref> Though technically it did not constitute a breach of loyalty towards the Carlist king, Minguijón concluded that Carlism was no longer offering a viable solution. He confirmed his commitment to Traditionalist values, but in terms of political strategy he perceived Carlism a dead-end street: Don Jaime was deprived of descendants and acting as a party leader rather than as a king,<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 204</ref> while the movement trapped in dynastical intransigence was deprived of any allies.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 202-3</ref> Determined to seek broad partnership on minimalist basis, Minguijón left Jaimismo in 1920.<ref>Canal 2000, p. 279, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 202</ref> [[File:ULL.98.43.11.23.jpg|thumb|160px|[[:es:Severino Aznar|Severino Aznar]]]] In 1922 Minguijón co-issued<ref>with Inocencio Jimenez and conde de Valldellano, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 231</ref> a manifesto launching [[:es:Partido Social Popular|Partido Social Popular]];<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 232-2</ref> he was among the Zaragoza socially-minded theorists,<ref>dubbed "grupo coordinador de Zaragoza", including also Inocencio Jimenez and Genaro Poza, Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 221, Alares López 2013, p. 20. On catolicismo social in Aragón, see Eloy Fernández Clemente, Carlos Forcadell, ''Los orígenes del catolicismo social (1890-1910)'', [in:] ''Aragón Contemporáneo. Estudios'', Zaragoza 1986, pp. 79-188, José Estarán Molinero, ''Catolicismo social en Aragón (1878-1901)'', Zaragoza 2001, his also ''Cien años de «Acción Social Católica de Zaragoza» (1903-2003)'', Zaragoza 2003</ref> one of six streams which merged in the new organization.<ref>formed also by tradicionalismo mellista, izquierda maurista, ACNDP and the Catholics; Fernández Riquelme 2008, pp. 220-1</ref> The party, inspired by social encylicae of [[Leo XIII]],<ref>Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 2008, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, p. 36</ref> is considered the first Spanish incarnation of Christian Democracy; Minguijón co-authored its ''Programa mínimo'' and enthusiastically advocated its broad platform as allegedly deprived of sectarian particularism;<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 233-4</ref> the party focus was on social issues tackled within a broad Catholic perspective.<ref>the Carlist political leader, marqués de Villores, issued a warning preventing the Carlists from assisting PSP; the party was referred to as recurrence of Pidalismo, Canal 2000, p.279</ref> In PSP Minguijón remained one of key theorists, though the party was by no means short of them, having in its ranks also Severino Aznar, Inocencio Jiménez, [[:es:Rafael Aizpún|Rafael Aizpún]], [[José Ibáñez Martín]], [[José María Gil-Robles]], Ángel Ossorio y Gallardo and [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Víctor Pradera]]. The organization, intended as agglutinatory force beyond a future broad right-wing platform, proved to have been just en episode; like all other political parties it was dissolved by the [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] dictatorship in 1923.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref>
==Dictatorship== [[File:ULL.75.46.83.11.jpg|thumb|left|[[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo]] with the Aragon [[:es:Somatén|Somatén]]]] Shortly after the [[March on Rome]] Minguijón defined [[Fascism]] as a sane response to social disunity and administrative chaos, the problems haunting Spain as well; though he refrained from endorsing violence and dictatorship, Minguijón noted that also in his country "tenemos necesidad de depuración y de disciplina".<ref>''El Día de Palencia'' 02.06.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2202833&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Upon the advent of the Primo de Rivera dictatorship two months later he greeted the developments with cautious optimism;<ref>''El Debate'' 26.09.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2285202&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> by the end of 1923 the pesepistas voiced their support for renewal and "reconstitución" of political setting. Underlining no support for violence, they hoped for increased social work, making vague references to agrarian reform, syndical liberties, cheap credit, municipal self-government and advanced labor legislation.<ref>''El Debate'' 29.12.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=2285445&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Many former PSP members, most notably Víctor Pradera, emerged as key theorists behind the primoderiverista regime; however, Minguijón was not visible in the front row of its supporters. He focused mostly on quasi-political work adhering to the Christian-Democratic format, at that time championed mostly by Asociación Católica Nacional de Propagandistas. In 1923-1926 he engaged in Círculo de Estudios, a think-tank born out of ACNDP,<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 300</ref> giving lectures on social and political issues as well as publishing articles in specialized reviews. Many of them focused on his favorite topic, the question of property, advancing a thesis that increasing ownership among wide social strata was the best strategy for confronting both poverty and revolution.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 309</ref> In 1926 he engaged in building [[:es:Organización Corporativa Nacional|Organización Corporativa Nacional]], the nationwide labor organization, by scholars counted among representatives of "tradicionalismo mellista".<ref>Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 279</ref>
In the late 1920s Minguijón was active discussing structure and composition of the new state diet. Acknowledging that the freshly formed [[:es:Asamblea Nacional Consultiva|Asamblea Consultiva]] was merely a stepping stone towards the ultimate Asamblea Nacional, he fully agreed with its corporative format, in line with the theory of organic democracy. Engaging in polemics with other theorists like Ossorio y Gallardo he rather discussed components of the parliament, advocating slightly larger granularity of its structure.<ref>Mariano García Canales, ''La teoría de la representación en la España del siglo XX: (de la crisis de la restauración a 1936)'', Madrid 1977, {{ISBN|9788460010531}}, p. 101</ref> Himself he did not emerge as major [[Patriotic Union (Spain)|Unión Patriótica]] official<ref>it is known only that he closely co-operated with UP, Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 73</ref> and was not appointed to the quasi-parliament; it is not clear whether, except relations with Pradera, he had access to Primo or any of key decision-makers of the regime. Tone of Minguijón's editorials, though never enthusiastic, cooled down over time; those from the late 1920s and 1930 are increasingly escapist. They discuss foreign policy, history, ideas, law, great personalities etc., but tend to evade current issues. They remain firm, however, in support of Catholic trade unions<ref>''Boletín de Acción Social'' December 1928, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=9&path=1000167175&forma=&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and Catholic social thought,<ref>''La Tierra'' 15.08.29, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=9&path=5015738&forma=&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> as well as in opposition to violence.<ref>also from the right; for Minguijón's anxiety related to violence of Legionarios de Albiñana see ''La Voz'' 04.12.30, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=9&path=2008513&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
==Republic== [[File:ULL.98.23.1.jpg|thumb|160px|left|Minguijon in press cartoon, [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] years]] Upon the advent of the Second Spanish Republic Minguijón did not join any political party and adopted a position of an observer. In the spring of 1931 his press commentaries maintained an abstract, [[Aesopian language]].<ref>e.g. on May 7, 1931, in one of his very first commentaries after the fall of the monarchy, Minguijón discussed a manifesto of Liga de Unión Latina in Paris, see ''Las Provincias'' 07.05.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=15&path=1000319212&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In the months and years to come Minguijón assumed a more specific stance; though he declared himself a monarchist (with increasingly Alfonsist penchant),<ref>''Labor'' 29.08.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3028826&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> at the same time he advocated constructive work under the republican regime.<ref>''Labor'' 07.03.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3028748&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> His focus was invariably on social issues and the question of property.<ref>he compared agrarian reform to building a railway line across private property: you have to sacrifice individual good for common good; ''Labor'' 15.04.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3028761&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Lambasting elitism<ref>"¿Es que la nobleza existía verdaderamente entre nosotros ? ¿Es que desempeñaba una verdadera función social de dirección, de guía, de patronato? Ni lucha, ni estudio, ni sacrificio, ni preocupación por los problemas de nuestro tiempo. Deportes, apuestas, cuadras con hermosos caballos de carrera, Gran Peña, fiestas fastuosas, tertulias, amistades con algún astro de la torería, Monte-Cristo, Kasabal, frivolidad, vicio, incomprensión; de todo eso no ha quedado ninguna estela duradera", ''Acción Española'' 01.12.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003648988&page=103 here]</ref> and liberal outlook<ref>''La ciudad y los campos'' 19.05.34, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2165735&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he called for common good to take precedence over individual one and formulated his expectations in likewise spirit;<ref>''Heraldo de Almería'' 17.11.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2126648&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in practical terms, they centred on agrarian reform<ref>''Regíon'' 26.07.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=1000254696&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and tackling unemployment.<ref>''La Gaceta de Tenerife'' 16.02.34, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=5048595&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> All the above stemmed from Catholic and not socialist principles; Minguijón firmly voiced against divorce<ref>''El Día de Palencia'' 06.11.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2202028&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and called for civilization based on rural, traditional basis,<ref>''Labor'' 15.04.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3028761&presentacion=pagina here]; according to Minguijón, translation to urban milieu deprived rural masses of tradition and values ''Labor'' 09.03.36, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=5&path=3028640&presentacion=pagina here];</ref> though he did not declare himself alarmed by separation of state and church.<ref>''Región'' 19.06.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=3&path=1000254312&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Though in favor of common spirit, Minguijón opposed dictatorship of the majority<ref>''El Día de Palencia'' 11.03.32, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2199714&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and acknowledged the anti-democratic tide overwhelming Europe as a "crisis of liberty"; he compared [[Kingdom of Italy#Fascist regime .281922.E2.80.931943.29|Fascist]], [[Nazi Germany|Nazi]] and [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] regimes using the word "totalitario", though he also distinguished between them.<ref>''ABC'' 22.10.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1933/10/22/046.html here]</ref> Denying Fascist identity, he admitted superiority of the Italian system – respectful to religious and secular tradition – compared to the Soviet one,<ref>''El Día de Palencia'' 31.01.36, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=2199362&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> praising also [[Piłsudski]] for [[Battle of Warsaw (1920)|stopping bolshevism in 1920]] and [[Hitler]] for preventing a Bolshevik revolution in 1933.<ref>''La Cruz'' 30.11.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=3053578&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Minguijón denounced the Spanish revolutionary<ref>he denounced every revolution as chaotic bloodbath, ''Labor'' 20.06.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=2&path=3028791&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Left as inventing a Fascist menace but offering the same totalitarian solution;<ref>''La Gaceta de Tenerife'' 01.08.35, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=8&path=5048913&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> his own preference was for the [[Estado Novo (Portugal)|Salazar]] regime.<ref>"a nuestro lado tenemos una nación que ha salido de la anarquía y que lentamente se va reconstituyendo. Esta nacion no tiene un Mussolini, tiene un Oliveira Salazar", ''Correo de Tortosa'' 05.07.34</ref>
In 1933 Minguijón co-founded a Zaragoza-based Centro de Estudios Sociales, born out of ACNDP and formatted as an Aragon version of the Madrid-based Instituto Social Obrero;<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 413</ref> he published in periodicals issued by both think-tanks.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 458</ref> He remained active in Christian-Democratic realm, taking part in various international congresses.<ref>''Universalità e cultura nel pensiero di Luigi Sturzo'', Roma 2001, {{ISBN|9788849800937}}, p. 356</ref> Politically he drew closer to CEDA;<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> it was thanks to its votes, combined with support from other Right-wing groupings, that in October 1933 Minguijón was elected – according to some authors as "tradicionalista"<ref>Roberto Villa García, ''Las elecciones de 1933 en el País Vasco y Navarra'', Madrid 2007, {{ISBN|9788498491159}}, p. 29</ref> – to Tribunal de Garantías Constitucionales,<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> a 35-member body acting as the Republic's constitutional court.
Gaining seat in Tribunal suspended Minguijón's university career, enforced his transfer from Zaragoza to Madrid and reduced his activity as a press pundit, though he continued sending commentaries to various periodicals. As constitutional judge Minguijón found himself in an awkward position; the body was entrusted with safeguarding the juridical republican system, while at the same time he was growing increasingly disillusioned with legal order of the Republic. His struggle was reflected in a highly contested vote on the [[:ca:Llei de Contractes de Conreu|Catalan Leases Act]], known as Llei de Contractes de Conreu. The verdict was possibly the key pronouncement of the Tribunal durcing Minguijón's tenure and pertained to two issues: [[:es:Estatuto de autonomía de Cataluña de 1932|Catalan autonomy]] and the social question, the latter related to vineyard tenants’ status. The Tribunal, at that time dominated by conservatively minded judges, decided against the claims of the Catalans and the tenants; Minguijón did not share that opinion and recorded a votum separatum.<ref>Joaquim de Camps i Arboix, ''El parlament de Catalunya, (1932-1936)'', Barcelona 1976, {{ISBN|9788429711523}}, p. 146, Cristóbal Robles, Cristóbal Robles Muñoz, ''José María de Urquijo e Ybarra: opinión, religión y poder'', Madrid 1997, {{ISBN|9788400076689}}, p 577; for Minguijón's view as justified to the public see ''La Gaceta de Tenerife'' 22.07.34, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=1&path=5049024&forma=&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
==Civil War== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] The [[Spanish coup of July 1936|July 1936 coup]] caught Minguijón during a summer break in Zaragoza. The city was almost immediately captured by the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalists]] and most University professors did not hesitate to voice their enthusiastic support for the rebels.<ref>Angel Alcaide Fernández, ''El apoyo de la Universidad de Zaragoza a la sublevación militar de 1936'', [in:] Ignacio Peiró Martín, Guillermo Vicente y Guerrero (eds.), ''Estudios históricos sobre la Universidad de Zaragoza'', Zaragoza 2010, {{ISBN|9788499110479}}, pp. 339-351; he is neither mentioned in Angela Cenarro, ''La Reina de Hispanidad: fascismo y nacionalcatolicismo en Zaragoza. 1939-1945'', [in:] ''Revista de Historia Jerónimo Zurita'' 72 (1997), pp. 91-102</ref> Minguijón is not listed either among most active advocates of the cause or among those engineering purges at the University,<ref>Alcaide Fernández 2010, pp. 342-3</ref> though at some point he declared his backing.<ref>Carlos Pulpillo Leiva, ''Orígenes del franquismo: la construcción de la "Nueva España" (1936-1941)'' [PhD thesis Universidad Rey Juan Carlos], Madrid 2013, p. 85</ref> In September he formally resigned from the anyway defunct Tribunal and resumed teaching at his usual History of Law chair in University of Zaragoza, the role performed for 2 years until in November 1938 he was nominated to a newly established Nationalist high court, Tribunal Supremo.<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014. The Tribunal first convened in May 1939 in Madrid, Carlos Jiménez Villarejo, ''La destrucción del orden republicano (apuntes juridicos)'', [in:] ''Hispania Nova'' 7 (2007), p. 15</ref> Having abandoned Aragón – this time for good – he resumed his highest judge role and formally contributed to forging of the [[Francoism|Francoist system]]; until 1950 the Tribunal consisted of appointees deemed utterly loyal and entrusted with juridical institutionalization of the regime.<ref>Francisco J. Bastida Freijedo, ''El pensamiento político del Tribunal Supremo en la Dictadura franquista'', [in:] ''Cronica Popular'' 20.11.14, available [http://www.cronicapopular.es/2014/11/el-pensamiento-politico-del-tribunal-supremo-en-la-dictadura-franquista/ here]</ref>
According to a contemporary scholar, during the Civil War Minguijón was also vital to forging of the emerging Nationalist ideology.<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 60</ref> His part was about contributions to ''Noticiero de España'', a Burgos-based bulletin issued by Servicios de Prensa y Propaganda and created to disseminate official ideas of the emerging state;<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 17</ref> within its editorial board he formed a group dubbed "juristas",<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, pp. 84-5</ref> considered also representative of "Traditionalists and Church".<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, pp. 719-720</ref> There were 63 issues of ''Noticiero'' published during its most prolific phase; there are 9 Minguijón's articles identified, published between May 1938 and August 1939.<ref>there are 9 Minguijón's articles identified, published on 28.5.38, 5.8.38, 3.9.38, 17.9.38, 18.2.39, 25.3.39, 29.4.39, 1.7.39, 12.8.39, see Pulpillo Leiva 2013</ref> [[File:Logotipo de Noticiero de Espana.jpg|thumb|logotype of ''Noticiero de España'']] Minguijón's role in ''Noticiero'' is described as related mostly to delegitimization of the Republic.<ref>along with Melchor Fernandez Almagro. Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 155</ref> Its regime was portrayed as climax of bolshevization which commenced in [[Bolshevik Revolution|Russia in 1917]] but manifested itself in Spain in [[:es:Sublevación de Jaca|Jaca in 1930]], in [[Asturian Uprising of 1934|Asturias in 1934]] and following the victory of [[Spanish general election, 1936|Frente Popular in 1936]];<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, pp. 161-2, 170</ref> Minguijón argued that the Republican regime abandoned its own rules,<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, pp. 90-91</ref> decomposed into anarchy<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 205; "el Movimiento nacionalista no se alzó contra un régimen, sino contra la ausencia de régimen, no contra un Gobierno, sino contra la una carencia de Gobierno, no contra una legalidad, sino contra una anarquía", quoted after Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 263</ref> and lost legitimacy;<ref>thesis laid out in ''La cuestión española. Legalidad Republicana'' of February 18, 1939</ref> moreover, it turned against democratic principles and rising of genuine Spain was necessary,<ref>''El alzamiento era inevitable'', referred after Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 173</ref> also to restore them.<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 197</ref> He wrote about the Republic with bitterness and visible disappointment, lamenting that the regime was trapped in contradictions: it failed to eradicate domination of the privileged classes and to introduce reforms based on the will of the people.<ref>"Una República que se instaura por voluntad del pueblo; unas clases privilegiadas que no se resignan a perder sus privilegios; la República liberal, progresiva, democrática que quiere libertar al pueblo oprimido; los privilegiados que se conjuran contra ella; el Gobierno atacado por los rebeldes; las oligarquías contra la democracia; la fuerza contra el derecho, etc. etc.", quoted after Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 241</ref> All these hopes were now laid in the emerging Nationalist state.<ref>"No hay derecho sino en el Estado y por el Estado. El mundo de la conciencia, los derechos fundamentales de las personas humanas, las afirmaciones del derecho natural, las ideas que se presentan como interiorización de nuestra conciencia de una superrealidad fundamental llamada a dominar las realidades contingentes, todo eso queda suprimido en una concepción tan radicalmente estatista", quoted after Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 826</ref> The earlier Minguijón's skepticism about Fascism gave way to cautious endorsement; he dubbed earlier comparisons between Fascism and [[Communism]] superficial<ref>see his ''Fascism in Spain'', [in:] J. Bayo, ''Spain'', New York 1939, pp. 5-7</ref> and in one of his last articles published in ''Noticiero'', dated July 1939, he analyzed where Fascism overlapped with Traditionalism, having found 6 points that both had in common.<ref>"[1] El fascismo es teísta, es decir, respeta y fomenta los va-lores y las instituciones religiosas. [2] Utilizando las palabras de Henri Mazel de la revista Mercure de France del 15 de septiembre de 1935 co-menta que el fascismo respeta la libertad y la dignidad individual, la propiedad y el ahorro, la familia y la patria, la moral y la religión, insertándose en un orden civiliza-cional. [3] Ideología que se representa como reanudadora de las tra-diciones de la antigua Roma para recuperar la gloria del Imperio antiguo [4] Importante culto a la infancia y a la juventud sobre la que ha de insertarse los valores de la tradición histórica [5] Inculca en la población disciplina de acción prosperidad y orden [6] A la larga también inculca la libertad del individuo pero siempre supeditada, en palabras de Mussolini, a la fe, la disciplina y la tenacidad", ''Caracteres del fascismo'', July 1, 1939, quoted [except numbering, inserted for convenience] after Pulpillo Leiva 2013, pp. 731-732</ref>
==Francoism==
Following the Nationalist capture of Madrid Minguijón settled in the city, where he resumed his academic career at history of law and at sociology in Universidad Central;<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 530</ref> his teaching influenced the next generation of Traditionalists like [[Rafael Gambra Ciudad|Rafael Gambra]], who attended Minguijón's lectures and were to gain prominence in the 1960s.<ref>Gambra 1959, pp. 82-83</ref> None of the sources consulted provides information on Minguijón's role in Tribunal Supremo; the entire body is known mostly for retroactively reversing many components of the Republican legislation.<ref>Jiménez Villarejo 2007, pp. 10, 12, 15, 16, 23</ref> He did not assume any official posts in state administration; he is neither noted as active in political structures, be it [[Falange Española Tradicionalista y de las Juntas de Ofensiva Nacional Sindicalista|Falangist]] or otherwise. In 1940 he entered the national executive of [[Acción Católica]],<ref>''Boletin Oficial del Obispado de Orihuela'' 16.05.40, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?interno=S&posicion=13&path=4001712&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> occasionally giving lectures and publishing in AC periodicals.
Having retired from the Tribunal and the university in 1944<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2014</ref> he focused on various duties in Real Academia de Ciencias Morales y Políticas, Institución Fernando el Católico, Colegio de Aragón, [[Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cientificas]] and especially in Instituto Balmes de Sociología, created by CSIC as the brainchild of Severino Aznar.<ref>Jesús Ibanez (ed.), ''Las ciencias sociales en España. Historia inmediata, crítica y perspectivas'', vol. 1: ''Sociología'', Madrid 1992, {{ISBN|9788474914061}}, p. 58</ref> Due to his age and health, these activities declined sharply in the early 1950s; his last identified lecture in Real Academia took place in 1951<ref>''ABC'' 07.11.51, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1951/11/07/020.html here]</ref> and his engagement in Instituto Balmes became loose after 1953.<ref>Alares López 2013, p. 267 and onwards</ref>
During Francoism Minguijón did not resume his longtime career of a press pundit, limiting himself to scientific and semi-scientific articles in specialized or Catholic reviews.<ref>e.g. Criterio, see ''ABC'' 15.06.48, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1948/06/15/016.html here]</ref> Little is known about his personal views on the developing Francoist system. In the press he was quoted as pursuing his interest in social question and praising social institutions of the Nationalist Spain, especially [[:es:Instituto Nacional de Previsión|Instituto Nacional de Previsión]], for their efficiency, at least compared to the Republican efforts.<ref>''ABC'' 01.10.41, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1941/10/01/018.html here]</ref> He admitted Traditionalist outlook,<ref>Gambra 1959, p. 86</ref> though he is not recorded as active in any Carlist branch of the time.<ref>see e.g. Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009</ref> He was recollected as skeptical – also in private - about both democracy and capitalism, deemed anonymous and amorphous forces which should be confronted by "localismo cultural", based on tradition and – inevitably - small property.<ref>Gambra 1959, pp. 86-7</ref>
Shortly before death Minguijón was described as a lonely old man, visited by a handful of disciples and few lifelong friends, like Severino Aznar; on the other hand, he remained perfectly lucid, serene, humble, as usual slightly ironic and far from any emphasis. Waking up around mid-day and working late into night, he was busy writing a treaty tailored as popularization of great philosophical concepts; it was supposed to amalgamate them within a new vision, intended for the future.<ref>"vulgarización de las grandes concepciones físicas y filosóficas del presente, tomadas en aquel punto en que coinciden y se completan para darnos una visión nueva del mundo en que vivimos. Una visión que enlaza asimismo la problematice política y social d nuestra época, en sus más profundas raíces", Gambra 1959, pp. 89-90</ref> His death was acknowledged by brief notes in some national newspapers; Colegio de Aragón organized a memorial homage session shortly afterwards.<ref>Alares López 2013, p. 382-3</ref>
==Reception and legacy== [[File:ULL.87.54.39.31.jpg|thumb|left|Minguijón Street, Zaragoza]] As a conservative theorist who strove to stimulate organization of the working class Minguijón failed; he is not noted as influencing Carlist syndicates either in their Catholic or [[pistolerismo (type or urban violence in Spain)|pistolerismo]] format.<ref>Minguijón is not a single time mentioned in works dealing with Catholic and Carlist syndicalism as developing in the early 20th century, compare Colin M. Winston, ''Carlist workers groups in Catalonia, 1900-1923'', [in:] Stanley G. Payne. (ed.), ''Identidad y nacionalismo en la España contemporánea: el carlismo, 1833-1975'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|8487863469}}, pp. 85-101, his also ''The Proletarian Carlist Road to Fascism: Sindicalismo Libre'', [in:] ''Journal of Contemporary History'' 17/1 (1982), pp. 557-585, his also ''Workers and the Right in Spain, 1900-1936'', Princeton 2014, {{ISBN|9781400858095}}</ref> However, already in the early 1910s Minguijón was noted in wide public discourse as "excelente periodista católico"<ref>''La lectura dominical'' 29.04.11, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001659420&page=12 here]</ref> or "ilustre publicista católico",<ref>''Revista Montserratina'' December 1917, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005027605&page=59 here]</ref> in the 1920s acknowledged also as "conocido sociologo".<ref>''Nuestro Tiempo'' October 1924, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002696758&page=76 here]</ref> When referred to as a law scholar, apart from the usual "catedrático"<ref>''Revista católica de cuestines sociales'' August 1929, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002737190&page=61 here], also "doctisimo catedrático", "sabio catedrático", "catedrático ilustre" etc</ref> he was occasionally hailed as "maestro".<ref>''Revista de ciencias jurídicas'' 1926, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005142279&page=100 here]</ref> In professional realm he gained name following the 1927 publication of ''Historia del derecho español'', in 1933 entering the elite of jurisprudence scholars when nominated to Tribunal de Garantias and finally acquiring the highest status available to an academic when nominated to Real Academia de Ciencias Morales y Políticas in 1940. It remains striking, however, that he was not invited to [[Real Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación]].
After Minguijón's death a street in Zaragoza and a college in his native Calatayud were named after him; in both cases the naming survived purges related to anti-Francoist backlash of the late 20th century and implementation of [[Historical Memory Law|Ley de Memoria Histórica]] of 2007.<ref>e.g. in an article discussing health care infrastructure in Zaragoza Minguijón is referred to as a Christian-Democrat, not a Carlist or a Francoist, see Isabel Delmás Gracia, ''Enfermeria y planificacion familiar en Aragon en el franquismo y transicion'' [MA thesis], Zaragoza 2014, p. 27</ref> None of his works has been re-published and the institutions he co-founded, Instituto Balmes and Colegio de Aragón, ceased to exist as separate units. In public discourse he was gradually falling into oblivion; since 1959 up to date the popular Madrid daily ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]'' mentioned him 7 times, in all cases briefly noting his name when discussing Christian-Democratic, Traditionalist or social thought;<ref>compare hemeroteca of ''ABC'', available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/ here]</ref> a contemporary scholar declared him a "completely forgotten figure".<ref>Manuelle Peloille, ''Notas sobre la recepcion de la recepción de la revolución rusa en España'', p. 4, available [https://www.academia.edu/7028869/NOTAS_SOBRE_LA_RECEPCION_DE_LA_REVOLUCI%C3%93N_RUSA_EN_ESPA%C3%91A here]</ref> Currently he is acknowledged only in major general encyclopedias, covered in very brief notes as "historiador del derecho", member of the high Tribunal and "periodista".<ref>''Minguijón Adrían, Salvador'' [in:] ''Gran Enciclopedia de España'', vol. 14, Zaragoza 1999, {{ISBN|9788487544149}}, p. 6537</ref> In specialized almanacs and reference dictionaries he appears as a scholar in philosophy.<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, pp. 529-531</ref>
Minguijón has earned no monograph so far. In historical literature he is noted mostly as a political theorist, though exact categorization might differ: he could be referred to as one of the first Christian-Democratic politicians and theorists in Spain,<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72, Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 529</ref> as a somewhat unorthodox Carlist who strove to modernize Traditionalism,<ref>Bartyzel 2002, p. 288, Fernández Riquelme 2008, p. 197; on the other hand, he is ignored in a recent large encyclopedica entry on Traditionalism, Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Tradicionalismo'', [in:] Javier Fernández Sebastián (ed.), ''Diccionario político y social del siglo XX español'', Madrid 2008, {{ISBN|9788420687698}}, pp. 1163-1173</ref> as a representative of corporativismo católico, democracia orgánica and católicismo social,<ref>Benjamín Oltra, Amando de Miguel, ''Bonpartismo y catolicismo. Una hipótesis sobre los orígenes ideológicos del franquismo'', [in:] ''Revista de Sociologia'' 8 (1978), p. 87, Sergio Fernández Riquelme, ''La Democracia Orgánica en Espańa [1943-1967]: los teóricos y las ideas'', [in:] ''Arbil'' 120, available [http://www.arbil.org/120demo.htm here]</ref> or as in the very recent work, as key contributor to theoretical vision of the emerging Francoism.<ref>Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 19; in the text he is noted 26 times</ref> Some authors straightforwardly declare Minguijón an enemy of democracy,<ref>Díaz Díaz 1995, p. 531</ref> some prefer qualified applications like "democristiano"<ref>Baltar Rodriguez 2013, p. 72, ''Minguijón y Adrián, Juan Salvador'' [in:] ''Gran Enciclopedia Aragonesa'' online, available [http://www.enciclopedia-aragonesa.com/voz.asp?voz_id=8834 here]</ref> and some quote him speaking passionately against "democracia individualista y caótica",<ref>Oltra, de Miguel 1978, p. 87</ref> while declaring that only a [[Corporatism|corporative system]] ensured genuine democracy.<ref>contributing to the Francoist periodical in midst of the Civil War (September 1938) he wrote that the Republic was "un régimen basado en la voluntad del pueblo. Y en buen régimen democrático la voluntad del pueblo habrá de ser respetada siempre, lo mismo cuando nos agrade que cuando no nos agrade. Esa es la democracia. Nosotros no conocemos otra"; the problem was that the Frentepopulistas did not respect democracy, referred after Pulpillo Leiva 2013, p. 197</ref> Few authors recognize him as one of sociology pioneers in Spain, the follower of [[Jaime Balmes]].<ref>Bartyzel 2015, pp. 16, 64, also Oltra, de Miguel 1978, p. 86</ref>

'''Sigríður Þorgeirsdóttir''' (born 1958 in [[Iceland]]) is professor of [[philosophy]] at the [[University of Iceland]]. In 1997 she was the first woman to become a member of the Faculty of Philosophy at the University of Iceland. Prior to that she lectured in philosophy at [[Rostock University]]. She was Jane and Aatos Erkko professor at [[Helsinki Collegium for Advanced Studies]] 2014-2015, [[University of Helsinki.]]
== Education == Sigríður graduated from [[University of Boston|Boston University]] in 1981. She pursued graduate studies in Boston and at [[Freie Universität Berlin]] where she finished her master's degree in 1988. In 1993 she completed her doctoral studies at the [[Humboldt-Universität Berlin|Humboldt-Universität]] in Berlin.
== Philosophy == Sigríður specializes in the [[Friedrich Nietzsche|philosophy of Nietzsche]], [[feminist philosophy]] and philosophy of nature and embodiment. She has interpreted Nietzsche's philosophy of the body and sexual difference in terms of its influence on feminist and women thinkers of the 20th century, from [[Hannah Arendt]] and [[Simone de Beauvoir]] to [[Luce Irigaray]] and [[Judith Butler]]. She has published works on feminist philosophy, the philosophy of Arendt and Beuvoir, and recently introductory texts to women in the history of philosophy. In her writings on philosophy of embodiment and nature, the notions of relationality and connectedness are central. This also influences her recent work on economy and morals, such as in studies on the debt-economy.
== Administrative work == Sigríður is one of the founders of the [[United Nations University GEST—Gender Equality Studies and Training Programme]], a joint project of the United Nations University, University of Iceland and the Ministry for Foreign Affairs. She serves on the Academic Advisory Board of the Helsinki Collegium for Advanced Studies. She is on the board of [[FISP]], the world organisation of philosophical societies that organizes the World Congress of Philosophy, and chair of its committee for gender issues. The Department of Philosophy at the University of Iceland hosts the [[Erasmus Summer Schools in Gender and Philosophy]] that Sigríður runs with colleagues from the universities of Jyväskylä in Finland, Oslo in Norway and Aalborg in Denmark.
== Publications ==
=== Books === *''Dagbók 2016 - Árið með heimspekingum" (A Calendar of Women Philosophers), University of Iceland Press, 2015 (co-authored with Erla Karlsdóttir, Eyja M. Brynjarsdóttir and Nanna Hlín Halldórsdóttir). *''Dagbók 2014 - Árið með heimspekingum" (A Calendar of Women Philosophers), University of Iceland Press, 2013. *''Hannah Arendt. Af ást til heimsins", (collection of writings by Arendt edited and with an introduction by S. Thorgeirsdottir), Reykjavik: University of Iceland Press, 2011. *''Birth, Death, and Femininity: Philosophies of Embodiment'' (with R.M. Schott (ed.), V. Songe-Möller, S. Heinämaa), Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2010. * ''Kvenna megin'' [collection of essays in feminist philosophy], Reykjavík: Hið íslenska bókmenntafélag, 2001. * ''Vis creativa. Kunst und Wahrheit in der Philosophie Friedrich Nietzsches'', Würzburg: Königshausen & Neumann, 1996.
=== Co-editor of books === * ''The Body Unbound: Philosophical Perspectives on Religion, Embodiment, and Politics'' (with M. T. Mjaaland, O. Sigurdson (eds.)), Cambridge: Cambridge Scholars Press (forthcoming). * ''Simone de Beauvoir. Heimspekingur, rithöfundur, femínisti'' (with I. Erlingsdóttir (eds.)) [Collection of essays on the work of [[Simone de Beauvoir|S. de Beauvoir]]], Reykjavik: University of Iceland Press, 1999. * ''Fjölskyldan og réttlætið'' (with M. D. Baldursson and J. Á. Kalmansson (eds.)) [Collection of essays on The Family and Justice], Reykjavik: University of Iceland Press, 1997.

''For the Benedictine order, see [[Sisters of the Reparation of the Holy Face]]'' [[File:San Fior - Istituto Suore del Santo Volto - Foto di Paolo Steffan.jpg|thumb|Headquarters of the Sisters, the Holy Face Institute in [[San Fior]], Italy]] The '''Sisters of the Holy Face''' is a [[Roman Catholic]] religious organization for women.<ref name=BiogPia>[http://www.vatican.va/news_services/liturgy/saints/ns_lit_doc_20051113_mastena_en.html Vatican website: ''Biography of Maria Pia Mastena']</ref><ref name=MassPia>[http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/benedict_xvi/speeches/2005/november/documents/hf_ben_xvi_spe_20051113_beatifications_en.html Vatican website: ''Beatification of Maria Pia Mastena'', 13 November 2005]</ref> The members of the order use the abbreviation SSV after their names.<ref name=Annuario>[[Annuario Pontificio]] 2007, [[Libreria Editrice Vaticana]], Vatican City, {{ISBN|978-88-209-7908-9}} page 1723</ref>
The order was founded in [[San Fior]] in [[Treviso]] Italy in 1930 by Blessed [[Maria Pia Mastena]] (1881-1951). It was initially approved by the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Vittorio Veneto|Bishop of Vittorio Veneto]] on December 8, 1936 and the approval of the [[Congregation of Pontifical Right]] on 10 December 1947.<ref name=BiogPia/>
The order has 22 houses, including some in Brazil and Indonesia.

{{Zen Buddhism}} '''''Suizen''''' (吹禅) (“blowing Zen”) is a [[Zen]] practice consisting of playing the traditional Japanese [[shakuhachi]] [[bamboo]] [[flute]] as a means of attaining self-realization.<ref name=":0">''The Annals of the International Shakuhachi Society'', Volume 1. Ed. Dan E Mayers [n.d., c. 1996?]: Christopher Blasdel, “The Shakuhachi: Aesthetics of a single tone,” p. 13.</ref> Suizen was traditionally practised by the [[Komusō]] (“monks of emptiness”), the Zen Buddhist monks of the [[Fuke-shū|Fuke]] sect of Japan who flourished during the [[Edo period]] (1600 to 1868).
Instrumental music is rare in all Buddhist practice where instruments usually accompany ritual chants if they are used at all. With ''suizen'', the playing of the shakuhachi as a spiritual exercise is at the core of the religious practice, making it unique in the world of Buddhism.<ref>''The Annals of the International Shakuhachi Society'', Volume 1. Ed. Dan E Mayers [n.d., 1996?]: Andreas B Gutzwiller, “The Japanese flute Shakuhachi and its music: it is foreign or just strange?,” p. 9</ref><ref>Gutzwiller, Andreas, ''Die Shakuhachi der Kinko-Schule. Studien zur traditionallen Musik Japans''. Vol. 5, 2nd Edn., Florian Noetzel Verlag, Heinrichshofen-Bücher, Wilhelmshaven 2005. Pp. 20-22. {{ISBN|3-7959-0845-0}}</ref>
The practice of ''suizen'' may be understood in the context of both ancient Buddhist and Chinese classics which exerted a profound influence on Japanese music, which used awareness of sound as a medium of enlightenment.<ref name=":0" />
Breath is also of fundamental significance as the standard practice of sitting Zen meditation (''[[zazen]]'') and so there is a natural link between ''zazen'' and ''suizen''. The type of breathing technique required varies from school to school within ''suizen''.<ref>''The Annals of the International Shakuhachi Society'', Volume 1. Ed. Dan E Mayers [n.d., 1996?]: Ralph Samuelson, “Toward an understanding of Shakuhachi Honkyoku,” p. 32</ref>
The concept of ''ichi on jo butsu'' – the attainment of enlightenment through a single note – became an important aspect of the ''Fuke'' sect’s ‘blowing Zen’ as it developed in later periods.<ref>''The Annals of the International Shakuhachi Society'', Volume 1. Ed. Dan E Mayers [n.d., 1996?]: Christopher Blasdel, “The Shakuhachi: Aesthetics of a single tone,” p. 14</ref> The sound produced by the instrument, which was taught along strict and traditional lines in the ''suizen'' schools, is not considered important. It is the practice of blowing which leads to enlightenment.
In 1823 Hisamatsu Fūyō (Hisamatsu Masagoro Suga no Sandaharu – c. 1790s to c. 1880s) published his short treatise on ''suizen'' practice, Hitori Mondō (“self-questioning”).<ref>''The Annals of the International Shakuhachi Society'', Volume 1. Ed. Dan E Mayers [n.d., 1996?]: Robin Hartshorne and Kazuaki Tanahashi, “The hitori mondo of Hisamatsu Fuyo,”pp. 41-45.</ref><ref>Reproduced in full in Gutzwiller 2005 (see footnote 3, above), pp. 175-188 (German and Japanese text), with a comprehensive analysis on pp. 149-155.</ref> Here, Hisamatsu Fūyō speaks of “going all the way with intellect and then going beyond intellect” on the path to enlightenment. He distinguishes the form (''jitsu'') of shakuhachi music played for entertainment from the emptiness (''kyo'') of Zen instrumental practice.<ref>''The Annals of the International Shakuhachi Society'', Volume 1. Ed. Dan E Mayers [n.d., 1996?]: Robin Hartshorne and Kazuaki Tanahashi, “The hitori mondo of Hisamatsu Fuyo,”p. 44.</ref>
The shakuhachi repertoire derives from the Fuke original solo pieces, the ''[[Honkyoku]].'' For suizen practitioners these are traditionally played in the manner of a personal spiritual practice and not as a public performance.<ref>''The Annals of the International Shakuhachi Society'', Volume 1. Ed. Dan E Mayers [n.d., 1996?]: Ralph Samuelson, “Toward an understanding of Shakuhachi Honkyoku,” p. 33.</ref>
The traditions of Fuke Zen and ''suizen'' continue today both in Japan and around the world.

The '''tax on childlessness''' ({{lang-ru|налог на бездетность|translit=nalog na bezdetnost}}) was imposed in the [[Soviet Union]] and other Communist countries, starting in the 1940s, as part of their [[Natalism|natalist]] policies. [[Joseph Stalin]]'s regime created the tax in order to encourage adult people to reproduce, thus increasing the number of people and the [[Soviet Union#Population and society|population of the Soviet Union]]. The 6% income tax affected men from the age of 25 to 50, and [[Wife|married women]] from 20 to 45 years of age.<ref name = "russian_tax">"Tax on childlessness, which existed in the Soviet Union, proposed to be restored" ("Налог на бездетность, существовавший в СССР, предлагают восстановить") http://www.finiz.ru/cfin/tmpl-art/id_art-1054929 (accessed January 3, 2010.)</ref>
The tax remained in place until the [[collapse of the Soviet Union]], though by the end of the [[Soviet Union]], the amount of money which could be taxed was steadily reduced. Minister of Health [[Mikhail Zurabov]] and Deputy Chairman of the State Duma Committee for Health Protection [[Nikolai Gerasimenko]] proposed reinstating the tax in [[Russia]] in 2006, but so far it has not been reinstated.<ref name = "pravda">"Childless Russian families to pay taxes for their social inaction," http://english.pravda.ru/russia/economics/15-09-2006/84467-childless-0 (accessed January 3, 2010.)</ref>
==Russia== As originally passed and enforced from 1941 to 1990, the tax affected most childless men from 25 to 50 years of age, and most childless married women from 20 to 45 years of age. The tax was 6% of the childless person's wages, but it provided certain exceptions: those with children that died during [[World War II]] did not have to pay the tax, nor did war heroes that received certain awards. Also, many students were able to obtain an exemption from the tax, as did people who earned less than 70 [[Russian ruble|rubles]] a month. Furthermore, those who were medically incapable to give birth were also exempt to this tax, and many single men fraudulently escaped the tax by claiming infertility and provided fake medical documentation.<ref name = "russian_tax" />
After 1990, the income exemption was increased to 150 rubles, meaning that the first 150 rubles of income for childless adults went untaxed.<ref name = "table">"On the phasing out of the tax on single men and small families of Soviet citizens" (О ПОЭТАПНОЙ ОТМЕНЕ НАЛОГА НА ХОЛОСТЯКОВ, ОДИНОКИХ И МАЛОСЕМЕЙНЫХ ГРАЖДАН СССР) http://www.businesspravo.ru/Docum/DocumShow_DocumID_37788.html (accessed January 3, 2010.)</ref> In 1991, the tax was changed to no longer apply to women, and in 1992, it was rendered irrelevant and inactive due to the collapse of the Soviet Union.
==Poland== In 1946, communist Poland introduced a similar increase of the basic income tax rate, in effect a tax on childlessness, popularly called ''[[:pl:Bykowe|bykowe]]'' in Polish ("bull's tax", the "bull" being a metonymy for an unmarried man). First, childless and unmarried people over 21 years of age were affected (from 1 January 1946 till 29 November 1956), then only over 25 years of age (30 November 1956 till 1 January 1973).<ref>Art. 20 Personal Income Tax Decree of 26 Oct 1950, Dz.U. No. 7 of 1957 r., Item 26.</ref>
==Romania== {{See|Decree 770}} Taxes on childlessness were part of the natalist policy introduced by [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]] in [[Communist Romania]] in the period 1967-1990. Along with the outlawing of abortion and contraception (1967) and mandatory gynecological revisions, these taxes were introduced in various forms in 1977 and 1986. Unmarried citizens had to pay penalty for childlessness, the tax income rate being increased by 8-10% for them.<ref name="Kligman short">Kligman, Gail. "Political Demography: The Banning of Abortion in Ceausescu's Romania". In Ginsburg, Faye D.; Rapp, Rayna, eds. ''Conceiving the New World Order: The Global Politics of Reproduction.'' Berkeley, CA: University of California Press, 1995 :234-255. Unique Identifier : AIDSLINE KIE/49442.</ref><ref name="prezi">{{cite web|url=http://prezi.com/pxfer5mul7-1/romanian-pro-natalism/|title=Romanian Pro-Natalism by Max Rudert on Prezi|publisher=prezi.com|accessdate=2014-09-14}}</ref>
==Effects and Proposals== During the Soviet Union, Russia had a higher fertility rate than it did in the years after the fall of the Soviet Union, prompting some Russian leaders to propose bringing back the tax on childlessness.<ref name = "pravda" /> According to the Health Ministry, the total fertility rate dropped from 2.19 children/woman to 1.17 children/woman in the aftermath of the Soviet Union. According to the Russian Director of the Center for Demography [[Anatoly Vishnevsky]], this birth rate is among the lowest in the world, and Russian leaders have described the demographic issues in Russia as being symptomatic of a "crisis."
While the tax on childlessness has not been re-enacted, other proposals have been. For example, [[Vladimir Putin]] enacted a proposal to provide cash incentives for women who are willing to have a second child.<ref name = "putin">"A second baby? Russia's mothers aren't persuaded." http://www.csmonitor.com/2006/0519/p01s04-woeu.html (accessed January 3, 2009.)</ref>

{{Italic title}} '''''The Logic of Modern Physics''''' is a 1927 [[philosophy of science]] book by American physicist and Nobel laureate [[Percy Williams Bridgman]]. The book was widely read by scholars in the [[social sciences]], in which it had a huge influence in the 1930s and 1940s,<ref name="Crowther-Heyck2005p65"/> and its major influence on the field of psychology in particular surpassed even that on methodology in physics, for which it was originally intended.<ref name="Green1992myth"/> The book is notable for explicitly identifying, analyzing, and explaining [[operationalism]] for the first time,<ref name="Sarkar2005p76">Sarkar, Sahotra and Pfeifer, Jessica (2005) ''The Philosophy of Science: An Encyclopedia, Volume 1'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=od68ge7aF6wC&pg=PA76 p. 76]</ref> and coining the term [[operational definition]].
Operationalism can be considered a variation on the [[positivist]] theme, and, arguably, a very powerful and influential one.<ref name="Crowther-Heyck2005p65">Crowther-Heyck, Hunter (2005) ''Herbert A. Simon: The Bounds of Reason in Modern America'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=LV1rnS9NBjkC&pg=PA65 p. 65]</ref> Sir [[Arthur Eddington]]<ref>Eddington, A. (1920). ''[[s:Space Time and Gravitation]]''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.</ref> had discussed notions similar to operationalization before Bridgman, and [[American Pragmatism|pragmatic]] philosophers<ref>[[Charles Sanders Peirce|Peirce, C.S.]] (1955). How to make our ideas clear. In J. Buchler (Ed.), Philosophical writings of Peirce (pp. 23–41). New York: Dover. (Original work published 1878.)</ref> had also advanced solutions to the related ontological problems. Bridgman's formulation, however, became the most influential.<ref name="Green1992myth"/>
==Influence== In the social sciences, the main influence has been in psychology. The influence on psychology has been even greater than that on methodology in physics, for which it was originally intended.<ref name="Green1992myth">Green, Christopher D. (1992) ''[http://philsci-archive.pitt.edu/199/1/operat.htm Of Immortal Mythological Beasts: Operationism in Psychology]'' in ''Theory & Psychology'', 2, pp. 291–320</ref> Examples of the influence on psychology in the 1930s and 1940s include [[Stanley Smith Stevens]] (''The Operational Basis of Psychology'' and ''The Operational Definition of Psychological Concepts''), and [[Clark L. Hull]] (''The Principles of Behavior: An Introduction to Behavior Theory'').<ref name="Crowther-Heyck2005p352">Crowther-Heyck (2005) [https://books.google.com/books?id=LV1rnS9NBjkC&pg=PA352 p. 352] note 18</ref> Since then, it has been the central influence of the official [[epistemology]] governing psychological method for the whole century."<ref name="Koch1992p275">Koch, Sigmund (1992) ''Psychology's Bridgman vs. Bridgman's Bridgman: An Essay in Reconstruction.'', in ''[[Theory and Psychology]]'' vol. 2 no. 3 (1992) p. 275</ref> It was a major influence on [[behaviorism]].
